{"comments": {"id": 27896, "count": 125, "talk_id": 13476}, "threadId": 27896, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "13476", "description": "If you think democracy is broken, here's an idea: let's replace politicians with randomly selected people. Author and activist Brett Hennig presents a compelling case for sortition democracy, or random selection of government officials -- a system with roots in ancient Athens that taps into the wisdom of the crowd and entrusts ordinary people with making balanced decisions for the greater good of everyone. Sound crazy? Learn more about how it could work to create a world free of partisan politics.", "event": "TEDxDanubia", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Brett Hennig: What if we replaced politicians with randomly selected people?", "slug": "brett_hennig_what_if_we_replaced_politicians_with_randomly_selected_people", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "4026", "slug": "brett_hennig", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Brett", "lastname": "Hennig", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Author, activist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/8d0b2b811b8255be64e8557691d020283e61a06c_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Brett Hennig co-founded and directs the Sortition Foundation, which campaigns to institute the use of stratified, random selection (also called sortition) in government.", "whylisten": "

Before co-founding the Sortition Foundation, Brett Hennig wore a variety of hats: as a taxi driver, a software engineer, a social justice activist, a mathematics tutor and the primary carer of four boys. He finished his PhD in astrophysics just before his first son arrived.

After spending several disheartening years in civil society organizations and politics, Hennig became inspired by Michael Hardt and Antonio Negri's trilogy on political philosophy and began investigating and researching network forms of democracy. The resulting book, The End of Politicians: Time for a Real Democracy, has been called "a book for visionaries" by New Internationalist contributing editor James Kelsey Fry and described as "a powerful critique and provocative alternative" by late Professor Erik Olin Wright of the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

Hennig has given many talks promoting sortition and has contributed a chapter, "Who needs elections? Accountability, Equality, and Legitimacy under Sortition," to the book Legislature by Lot: Transformative Designs for Deliberative Governance (Verso, 2019).

Succinct. Inspiring. Combining insights from the history of democracy with a critical understanding of the information revolution, this book explains how we can fix democracy by eliminating politicians and replacing them with a representative network of everyday citizens.", "note": "Brett Hennig Unbound Digital, 2017", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/End-Politicians-Time-Real-Democracy/dp/1911586106/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Against Elections: The Case for Democracy*", "blurb": "Van Reybrouck argues that to inoculate against "democratic fatigue syndrome," we need a healthy dose of sortition in our politics. This compelling and convincing book is a must-read for everyone who wants to transform democracy and make it responsive to the informed will of the people.", "note": "David Van Reybrouck Random House, 2016", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Against-Elections-David-Van-Reybrouck/dp/1847924220/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Democracy for Realists: Why Elections Do Not Produce Responsive Governments*", "blurb": "Do you still believe in the "folk theory of democracy" -- that our politicians listen and respond to the public, and that people vote after a careful consideration of policy options and outcomes? This book explodes this popular myth, and explains in an understandable and accessible way the real story about what elections mean and do.", "note": "Christopher Achen and Larry Bartels Princeton University Press, 2017", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Democracy-Realists-Elections-Responsive-Government/dp/0691178240/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}]}, {"title": "Film", "description": "", "rec_items": [{"label": "WATCH", "headline": ""The 10 best short videos about sortition"", "blurb": "Want to watch more? "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Author, activist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/8d0b2b811b8255be64e8557691d020283e61a06c_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Brett Hennig co-founded and directs the Sortition Foundation, which campaigns to institute the use of stratified, random selection (also called sortition) in government.", "whylisten": "

Before co-founding the Sortition Foundation, Brett Hennig wore a variety of hats: as a taxi driver, a software engineer, a social justice activist, a mathematics tutor and the primary carer of four boys. He finished his PhD in astrophysics just before his first son arrived.

After spending several disheartening years in civil society organizations and politics, Hennig became inspired by Michael Hardt and Antonio Negri's trilogy on political philosophy and began investigating and researching network forms of democracy. The resulting book, The End of Politicians: Time for a Real Democracy, has been called "a book for visionaries" by New Internationalist contributing editor James Kelsey Fry and described as "a powerful critique and provocative alternative" by late Professor Erik Olin Wright of the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

Hennig has given many talks promoting sortition and has contributed a chapter, "Who needs elections? Accountability, Equality, and Legitimacy under Sortition," to the book Legislature by Lot: Transformative Designs for Deliberative Governance (Verso, 2019).

"}], "speaker_name": "Brett Hennig", "tags": ["politics", "policy", "government", "democracy", "leadership", "activism", "future", "history", "inequality", "social change", "society", "corruption", "TEDx"], "title": "What if we replaced politicians with randomly selected people?", "video_type": {"id": "2", "name": "TEDx Talk"}, "viewed_count": 1573306}]}
author: Brett_Hennig;
title: What if we replaced politicians with randomly selected people?
